etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in American Journal Pharmacy. From German Rhodinol from ancient Greek ῥόδινος of or from roses (from ῥόδον rose + -ινος) + German -ol

definitions: A fragrant liquid isolated from rose oil and other plant oils, and used in perfumery and cosmetics. In later use also: specifically one of the isomeric components of this liquid.

notes.text: Rhodinol consists largely of two isomeric open-chain terpenoid alcohols, and is identical to citronellol except in the proportions of these isomers; the name is specifically applied to 3,7-dimethyl-7-octen-1-ol. Formula: C₁₀H₂₀O.
